title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
Load the data variable:


random_vars <- readRDS("../../data/random_vars.rds")

View(random_vars)

random_vars



  




1 Question 1

For each variable, compute the following values. You can use the built-in functions or use the mathematical formulas.
- expected value, variance, standard deviation

computing the mean, variance and standard deviation


# for Age
expected_value_age <- mean(random_vars$age)
variance_age <- var(random_vars$age)
standard_deviation_age <- sd(random_vars$age)

# for Income
expected_value_income <- mean(random_vars$income)
variance_income <- var(random_vars$income)
standard_deviation_income <- sd(random_vars$income)


Printing mean, variance, standard deviation for age


cat("# Expected Value:  =", expected_value_age)

#> # Expected Value:  = 33.471

cat("# Variance Value:  =", variance_age)

#> # Variance Value:  = 340.6078

cat("# Standard Deviation Value:  =", standard_deviation_age)

#> # Standard Deviation Value:  = 18.45556



Printing mean, variance, standard deviation for Income


cat("# Expected Value:  =", expected_value_income)

#> # Expected Value:  = 3510.731

cat("# Variance Value:  =", variance_income)

#> # Variance Value:  = 8625646

cat("# Standard Deviation Value:  =", standard_deviation_income)

#> # Standard Deviation Value:  = 2936.945




2 Question 2

The standard deviations cannot be for atleast the provided dataset. The reason being, the variables assessed are age and income, which are measured in two different units and completely different scales. Therefore, it would not be ideal to compare these standard deviations.
The figures below are the plots of the Standard deviation of both Age and Income. We can see the scales and the distribution are completely different.

library(ggplot2)
ggplot(random_vars, aes(x = age)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 1, fill = 'blue', alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = expected_value_age), color = "red", linetype = "dashed", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = expected_value_age + standard_deviation_age), color = "red", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = expected_value_age - standard_deviation_age), color = "red", size = 1) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Age with Standard Deviation")

#> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
#> ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.








# Plot for 'income'
ggplot(random_vars, aes(x = income)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 100, fill = 'green', alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = expected_value_income), color = "blue", linetype = "dashed", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = expected_value_income + standard_deviation_income), color = "blue", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = expected_value_income - standard_deviation_income), color = "blue", size = 1) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Income with Standard Deviation")










3 Question 3
Then, examine the relationship between both variables and compute:
- covariance, correlation

#Calculating Covariance and Correlation
covariance <- cov(random_vars$age, random_vars$income)
correlation <- cor(random_vars$age, random_vars$income)


Printing covariance and correlation


cat("# Covariance:  =", covariance)

#> # Covariance:  = 29700.15

cat("# Correlation:  =", correlation)

#> # Correlation:  = 0.5479432




4 Question 4

Correlation is a relatively easier measure to interpret. It is dimensionless and can provide information on the strength of the relationship between two variables, which makes it a perfect measure to compare Age and Income when these variables are fundamentally on two different scales. It is standardized to a range of -1 to 1, where the sign indicates the direction of the relationship, and the magnitude indicates the strength.
As the age increases, the income tends to increase as well, roughly accounting for 54.8%. This does not imply causation but there is a tendency for income to rise as the age rises.
On the other hand, Covariance is 29700.15. This value does not seem to be sensible between age and income. These variables have two different scales, which directly have an effect on the value of the Covariance.


5 Question 5

Compute the conditional expected value for:
- E[income|age <= 18]
- E[income|age ∈ [18, 65]]
- E[income|age >= 65]

expected_value_teens <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age <= 18])
expected_value_adults <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age > 18 & random_vars$age <= 65])
expected_value_seniors <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age > 65])


Printing covariance and correlation


cat("# E[income|age <= 18]:  =", expected_value_teens)

#> # E[income|age <= 18]:  = 389.6074

cat("# E[income|age ∈ [18, 65]]:  =", expected_value_adults)

#> # E[income|age ∈ [18, 65]]:  = 4743.234

cat("# E[income|age >= 65]:  =", expected_value_seniors)

#> # E[income|age >= 65]:  = 1604.193

title: Causality
text:
1 Famous example: Nicolas Cage films and number of poeple drowned by falling into a pool
I came across this devious example of the number of people drowned by falling into a pool correlated with films Nicolas Cage appeared in during the same time period. I would like to recreate this example: https://www.datasciencecentral.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/2808309983.png

set.seed(99) # for reproducibility
years <- 2000:2009
cage_films <- cumsum(sample(1:5, 10, replace = TRUE))
drownings <- cumsum(sample(1:5, 10, replace = TRUE)) + rnorm(10, mean = 0, sd = 0.15)
data <- data.frame(Year = years, Cage_Films = cage_films, Drownings = drownings)


data



  




library(ggplot2)

# Line plot showing trends over time
ggplot(data, aes(x = Year)) + 
  geom_line(aes(y = Cage_Films, colour = "Nicolas Cage Films")) +
  geom_line(aes(y = Drownings, colour = "Drownings by falling into the pool")) +
  labs(title = "Spurious Correlation between Nicolas Cage Films and Drownings",
       y = "Count",
       colour = "Legend") +
  theme_minimal()







# Scatter plot showing the correlation
ggplot(data, aes(x = Cage_Films, y = Drownings)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Scatter Plot of Nicolas Cage Films vs Drownings",
       x = "Nicolas Cage Films",
       y = "Drownings by falling into the pool") +
  theme_minimal()

title: Probability Theory
text:
T - Being on time
T_not - Not being on time
S - Change in Scope
S_not - No change in scope

Defining the probabilities from the probability tree


P_S <- 0.3 
P_S_not <- 0.7  
P_T_given_S <- 0.2  
P_T_given_S_not <- 0.6  

P(T ∩ S) - P_T_and_S
(T ∩ ¬S) - P_T_and_S_not
P(¬T ∩ S) - P_not_T_and_S
P(¬T ∩ ¬S) - P_not_T_and_S_not

# Compute the joint probabilities
P_T_and_S <- P_S * P_T_given_S  
P_T_and_S_not <- P_S_not * P_T_given_S_not  
P_not_T_and_S <- P_S * (1 - P_T_given_S)  
P_not_T_and_S_not <- P_S_not * (1 - P_T_given_S_not)  


P_T_and_S  

#> [1] 0.06

P_T_and_S_not  

#> [1] 0.42

P_not_T_and_S  

#> [1] 0.24

P_not_T_and_S_not  

#> [1] 0.28



Sum of all probabilities


probabilities_sum <- P_T_and_S + P_T_and_S_not + P_not_T_and_S + P_not_T_and_S_not


probabilities_sum

#> [1] 1

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
1 Read the and check the dimensions


Load the data frame


car_prices <- readRDS("../../data/car_prices.rds")


dimensions <- dim(car_prices)

cat("# Dimensions of the dataframe:  =", dimensions)

#> # Dimensions of the dataframe:  = 181 22




2 Use appropriate commands to get a more detailed look at the data


summary(car_prices)

#>   aspiration         doornumber          carbody           drivewheel       
#>  Length:181         Length:181         Length:181         Length:181        
#>  Class :character   Class :character   Class :character   Class :character  
#>  Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character  
#>                                                                             
#>                                                                             
#>                                                                             
#>  enginelocation       wheelbase        carlength        carwidth    
#>  Length:181         Min.   : 86.60   Min.   :141.1   Min.   :60.30  
#>  Class :character   1st Qu.: 94.50   1st Qu.:166.3   1st Qu.:64.00  
#>  Mode  :character   Median : 96.50   Median :173.0   Median :65.40  
#>                     Mean   : 98.21   Mean   :173.3   Mean   :65.74  
#>                     3rd Qu.:100.40   3rd Qu.:180.2   3rd Qu.:66.50  
#>                     Max.   :120.90   Max.   :208.1   Max.   :72.30  
#>    carheight       curbweight    enginetype        cylindernumber    
#>  Min.   :47.80   Min.   :1488   Length:181         Length:181        
#>  1st Qu.:52.00   1st Qu.:2122   Class :character   Class :character  
#>  Median :53.70   Median :2410   Mode  :character   Mode  :character  
#>  Mean   :53.58   Mean   :2521                                        
#>  3rd Qu.:55.50   3rd Qu.:2910                                        
#>  Max.   :59.80   Max.   :4066                                        
#>    enginesize     fuelsystem          boreratio         stroke    
#>  Min.   : 61.0   Length:181         Min.   :2.540   Min.   :2.07  
#>  1st Qu.: 98.0   Class :character   1st Qu.:3.150   1st Qu.:3.08  
#>  Median :120.0   Mode  :character   Median :3.310   Median :3.23  
#>  Mean   :127.1                      Mean   :3.325   Mean   :3.23  
#>  3rd Qu.:141.0                      3rd Qu.:3.590   3rd Qu.:3.40  
#>  Max.   :326.0                      Max.   :3.940   Max.   :4.17  
#>  compressionratio   horsepower       peakrpm        citympg     
#>  Min.   : 7.000   Min.   : 48.0   Min.   :4200   Min.   :13.00  
#>  1st Qu.: 8.500   1st Qu.: 70.0   1st Qu.:4800   1st Qu.:19.00  
#>  Median : 9.000   Median : 95.0   Median :5200   Median :24.00  
#>  Mean   : 8.848   Mean   :106.2   Mean   :5182   Mean   :24.85  
#>  3rd Qu.: 9.400   3rd Qu.:116.0   3rd Qu.:5500   3rd Qu.:30.00  
#>  Max.   :11.500   Max.   :288.0   Max.   :6600   Max.   :49.00  
#>    highwaympg        price      
#>  Min.   :16.00   Min.   : 5118  
#>  1st Qu.:25.00   1st Qu.: 7609  
#>  Median :30.00   Median : 9980  
#>  Mean   :30.48   Mean   :12999  
#>  3rd Qu.:34.00   3rd Qu.:16430  
#>  Max.   :54.00   Max.   :45400

# Seeing the datatypes of the dataframe
str(car_prices)

#> Classes 'tbl_df', 'tbl' and 'data.frame':    181 obs. of  22 variables:
#>  $ aspiration      : chr  "std" "std" "std" "std" ...
#>  $ doornumber      : chr  "two" "two" "two" "four" ...
#>  $ carbody         : chr  "convertible" "convertible" "hatchback" "sedan" ...
#>  $ drivewheel      : chr  "rwd" "rwd" "rwd" "fwd" ...
#>  $ enginelocation  : chr  "front" "front" "front" "front" ...
#>  $ wheelbase       : num  88.6 88.6 94.5 99.8 99.4 ...
#>  $ carlength       : num  169 169 171 177 177 ...
#>  $ carwidth        : num  64.1 64.1 65.5 66.2 66.4 66.3 71.4 71.4 71.4 67.9 ...
#>  $ carheight       : num  48.8 48.8 52.4 54.3 54.3 53.1 55.7 55.7 55.9 52 ...
#>  $ curbweight      : num  2548 2548 2823 2337 2824 ...
#>  $ enginetype      : chr  "dohc" "dohc" "ohcv" "ohc" ...
#>  $ cylindernumber  : chr  "four" "four" "six" "four" ...
#>  $ enginesize      : num  130 130 152 109 136 136 136 136 131 131 ...
#>  $ fuelsystem      : chr  "mpfi" "mpfi" "mpfi" "mpfi" ...
#>  $ boreratio       : num  3.47 3.47 2.68 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.13 3.13 ...
#>  $ stroke          : num  2.68 2.68 3.47 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 ...
#>  $ compressionratio: num  9 9 9 10 8 8.5 8.5 8.5 8.3 7 ...
#>  $ horsepower      : num  111 111 154 102 115 110 110 110 140 160 ...
#>  $ peakrpm         : num  5000 5000 5000 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 ...
#>  $ citympg         : num  21 21 19 24 18 19 19 19 17 16 ...
#>  $ highwaympg      : num  27 27 26 30 22 25 25 25 20 22 ...
#>  $ price           : num  13495 16500 16500 13950 17450 ...

head(car_prices)



  



The data types are as follows: chr and num.
The numeric data seems to be both decimal and whole numbers and they are classified under num. We can perform mathematical operations like summing, avergaing and so on.
The strings are referred as characters data type. Operations like sorting, categorizing can be performed with this data type.


3 Run a linear regression. You want to explain what factors are relevant for the pricing of a car.


lm_model <- lm(price ~ ., data = car_prices)

summary(lm_model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ ., data = car_prices)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -5662  -1120      0    798   9040 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                        Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)          -36269.965  15460.866  -2.346 0.020354 *  
#> aspirationturbo        1846.206   1041.391   1.773 0.078386 .  
#> doornumbertwo           242.523    571.929   0.424 0.672172    
#> carbodyhardtop        -3691.743   1424.825  -2.591 0.010561 *  
#> carbodyhatchback      -3344.335   1238.359  -2.701 0.007757 ** 
#> carbodysedan          -2292.820   1356.014  -1.691 0.093043 .  
#> carbodywagon          -3427.921   1490.285  -2.300 0.022885 *  
#> drivewheelfwd          -504.564   1076.623  -0.469 0.640030    
#> drivewheelrwd           -15.446   1268.070  -0.012 0.990299    
#> enginelocationrear     6643.492   2572.275   2.583 0.010806 *  
#> wheelbase               -30.197     92.776  -0.325 0.745294    
#> carlength               -29.740     51.672  -0.576 0.565824    
#> carwidth                731.819    244.533   2.993 0.003258 ** 
#> carheight               123.195    134.607   0.915 0.361617    
#> curbweight                2.612      1.781   1.467 0.144706    
#> enginetypedohcv       -8541.957   4749.685  -1.798 0.074219 .  
#> enginetypel             978.748   1786.384   0.548 0.584619    
#> enginetypeohc          3345.252    933.001   3.585 0.000461 ***
#> enginetypeohcf          972.919   1625.631   0.598 0.550462    
#> enginetypeohcv        -6222.322   1236.415  -5.033 1.43e-06 ***
#> cylindernumberfive   -11724.540   3019.192  -3.883 0.000157 ***
#> cylindernumberfour   -11549.326   3177.177  -3.635 0.000387 ***
#> cylindernumbersix     -7151.398   2247.230  -3.182 0.001793 ** 
#> cylindernumberthree   -4318.929   4688.833  -0.921 0.358545    
#> cylindernumbertwelve -11122.209   4196.494  -2.650 0.008946 ** 
#> enginesize              125.934     26.541   4.745 5.00e-06 ***
#> fuelsystem2bbl          177.136    883.615   0.200 0.841400    
#> fuelsystemmfi         -3041.018   2576.996  -1.180 0.239934    
#> fuelsystemmpfi          359.278   1001.529   0.359 0.720326    
#> fuelsystemspdi        -2543.890   1363.546  -1.866 0.064140 .  
#> fuelsystemspfi          514.766   2499.229   0.206 0.837107    
#> boreratio             -1306.740   1642.221  -0.796 0.427516    
#> stroke                -4527.137    922.732  -4.906 2.49e-06 ***
#> compressionratio       -737.901    555.960  -1.327 0.186539    
#> horsepower               10.293     22.709   0.453 0.651035    
#> peakrpm                   2.526      0.634   3.983 0.000108 ***
#> citympg                 -90.352    166.647  -0.542 0.588538    
#> highwaympg              154.858    167.148   0.926 0.355761    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9415, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9264 
#> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


The number of ‘*’ indicates how significant the parameters are that affect the price of the car. From the table above, we can conclude that these factors play a significant role towards the price of the car:

carbodyhardtop,
carbodyhatchback,
carbodywagon,
enginelocationrear,
carwidth,
enginetypeohc,
enginetypeohcv,
cylindernumberfive,
cylindernumberfour,
cylindernumbersix,
cylindernumbertwelve,
enginesize,
stroke,
peakrpm


Both the R values are quite high, greater than 0.92, indicating that the model is biased.
Additionally, the statistical significance for all the variables mentioned above are less than 0.05



4 Choosing Regressor

I would like to choose the Engine Size as the Regressor.

Data type: As we see from the summary of the linear regression, the data type of the Engine Size is num or a numeric value.
Statistical Significance: The p-value is 5.00e-06. It seems to be significantly smaller than 0.05, indicating that the effect it has on the Price is quite high.
Effect it has on Price: The coefficient of the Engine Size is 125.934. This value indicates that for each unit increase in size, the price is expected to increase by 125.934 units, keeping other variable constants.



5 seat_heating


library(dplyr)

#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

car_prices <- mutate(car_prices, seat_heating = TRUE)

lm_model_seat_heating <- lm(price ~ . + seat_heating, data = car_prices)


Summary of the new model to see the coefficient of ‘seat_heating’


summary(lm_model_seat_heating)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ . + seat_heating, data = car_prices)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -5662  -1120      0    798   9040 
#> 
#> Coefficients: (1 not defined because of singularities)
#>                        Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)          -36269.965  15460.866  -2.346 0.020354 *  
#> aspirationturbo        1846.206   1041.391   1.773 0.078386 .  
#> doornumbertwo           242.523    571.929   0.424 0.672172    
#> carbodyhardtop        -3691.743   1424.825  -2.591 0.010561 *  
#> carbodyhatchback      -3344.335   1238.359  -2.701 0.007757 ** 
#> carbodysedan          -2292.820   1356.014  -1.691 0.093043 .  
#> carbodywagon          -3427.921   1490.285  -2.300 0.022885 *  
#> drivewheelfwd          -504.564   1076.623  -0.469 0.640030    
#> drivewheelrwd           -15.446   1268.070  -0.012 0.990299    
#> enginelocationrear     6643.492   2572.275   2.583 0.010806 *  
#> wheelbase               -30.197     92.776  -0.325 0.745294    
#> carlength               -29.740     51.672  -0.576 0.565824    
#> carwidth                731.819    244.533   2.993 0.003258 ** 
#> carheight               123.195    134.607   0.915 0.361617    
#> curbweight                2.612      1.781   1.467 0.144706    
#> enginetypedohcv       -8541.957   4749.685  -1.798 0.074219 .  
#> enginetypel             978.748   1786.384   0.548 0.584619    
#> enginetypeohc          3345.252    933.001   3.585 0.000461 ***
#> enginetypeohcf          972.919   1625.631   0.598 0.550462    
#> enginetypeohcv        -6222.322   1236.415  -5.033 1.43e-06 ***
#> cylindernumberfive   -11724.540   3019.192  -3.883 0.000157 ***
#> cylindernumberfour   -11549.326   3177.177  -3.635 0.000387 ***
#> cylindernumbersix     -7151.398   2247.230  -3.182 0.001793 ** 
#> cylindernumberthree   -4318.929   4688.833  -0.921 0.358545    
#> cylindernumbertwelve -11122.209   4196.494  -2.650 0.008946 ** 
#> enginesize              125.934     26.541   4.745 5.00e-06 ***
#> fuelsystem2bbl          177.136    883.615   0.200 0.841400    
#> fuelsystemmfi         -3041.018   2576.996  -1.180 0.239934    
#> fuelsystemmpfi          359.278   1001.529   0.359 0.720326    
#> fuelsystemspdi        -2543.890   1363.546  -1.866 0.064140 .  
#> fuelsystemspfi          514.766   2499.229   0.206 0.837107    
#> boreratio             -1306.740   1642.221  -0.796 0.427516    
#> stroke                -4527.137    922.732  -4.906 2.49e-06 ***
#> compressionratio       -737.901    555.960  -1.327 0.186539    
#> horsepower               10.293     22.709   0.453 0.651035    
#> peakrpm                   2.526      0.634   3.983 0.000108 ***
#> citympg                 -90.352    166.647  -0.542 0.588538    
#> highwaympg              154.858    167.148   0.926 0.355761    
#> seat_heatingTRUE             NA         NA      NA       NA    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9415, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9264 
#> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


From the table, we notice that the seat_heating has no impact on the price as the regressor model is unable to find any correlation between the price and seat_heating. Thats why the coefficient is NA. This could be due to the Perfect Multi-Collinearity. As the variable seat_heating is set to True and has no variation, the model cannot estimate a coefficient for it.

title: Probability Theory
text:
P_S <- 0.3 # Probability of a change in scope P_no_S <- 0.7 # Probability of no change in scope P_T_given_S <- 0.2 # Probability of being on time given a change in scope P_T_given_no_S <- 0.6 # Probability of being on time given no change in scope






Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh REALLY.


This is a .qmd file. It is plain text with special features. Any time you write just like this, it will be compiled to normal text in the website. If you put a # in front of your text, it will create a top level-header.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
section: 4.1 Explain what data type it is and what values it can take on
text:
4.1 Explain what data type it is and what values it can take on
I would like to choose the Engine Size as the Regressor.

Data type: As we see from the summary of the linear regression, the data type of the Engine Size is num or a numeric value.
